Israeli and American scientists have discovered in Ashkenazi Jews * a gene responsible for the development of schizophrenia, "schizoaffective disorder" and manic depression. According to a study recently published in Nature Communications, Ashkenazi Jews suffer from psychiatric illness at a rate of about 40%, or 15% of the general population.

The study was conducted by Prof. Ariel Darvasi(Darvasi), Deputy Dean of the Faculty of Sciences at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Dr. Todd Lentz(Lencz) from the Institute of Medical Research. Feinstein in New York.

The first part of the study included the largest group of Ashkenazi Jews ever surveyed. DNA samples were taken from 2,500 Ashkenazi Jews in Israel, revealing that 1,500 of them were healthy and 1,000 had mental disorders associated with schizophrenia. The study of the genetics of schizophrenia in Jews was due to the fact that Ashkenazis are considered the most homogeneous group, from a genetic point of view (they. in the process of self-segregation due to the ideology of Judaism, had the closest interrelationships that caused many genetic diseases ‚Äì approx. ed.).

The limited amount of genetic variation among Ashkenazi Jews makes it easy to identify differences between healthy and diseased people. Professor Darvasi has studied Ashkenazi Jews for many years and used the latest technology available to analyze the DNA samples he received for study.

"Today's technology allows for very comprehensive DNA analysis and the ability to read millions of pieces of a DNA strand in a very efficient scan," Darvasi told the Israeli publication Haaretz. In the first part of the study, scientists tested the prevalence of the NDST3 gene, which exists in 99.9% of the population. At the same time, there are 2 varieties of it, which help to identify patients with schizophrenia. The results of the study showed that gene variations in Ashkenazi Jews are responsible for a 40% increase in the risk of the disease.

Testing samples taken from Ashkenazi Jews was only the first part of the experiment. After which scientists began the second stage - a genetic study of other populations around the world. In the end, samples from more than 25,000 people from different ethnic groups in Europe, Asia and Africa were tested. In this group, "Jewish" scientists also found a correlation between the prevalence of schizophrenia of the NDST3 gene, although much less - increasing the risk of the disease by up to 15%.

The study was conducted over a 3-year period and was initially funded by a $2.1 million grant from the US National Institutes of Health. After receiving the first results, another grant of 3 million dollars was allocated to continue the research.
On average, up to 1% of the population suffers from schizophrenia - losing interest in the environment, experiencing negative emotions, "hearing voices" or "seeing numbers" that do not exist.

Many scientists believe that genes have a large influence on disease, along with environmental and hereditary (related to the moral behavior of ancestors).

Prof. Darvasi has been looking for a genetic link to schizophrenia for many years, primarily through research on a group of Ashkenazi Jews. In 2002, he led a group of scientists who argued that a gene called COMTeste one of the causes of the disease, responsible for about 20% of all cases of schizophrenia. ‚Äù We continue to find more information and discover more genes, hoping to report more discoveries in the future, primarily through more samples. That's what we're working on now."

Ashkenazi Jews have a genetic predisposition to schizophrenia

A joint study by Israeli and American scientists has identified a gene that increases the chances of Ashenazi Jews to develop mental disorders. This gene affects other populations to a lesser extent, according to Ido Efrati in Haaretz newspaper.

When the same gene is present in other populations, it increases their chances of developing mental illness by only 15%.
